steps.text: Amidst our quarantine, we wanted to understand what was happening to the subway system while we were stuck at home.
On average, the Metropolitan Transit Authority (MTA) records over 30 Million MetroCard swipes every week.

steps.text: In the first few months after COVID-19 arrived in New York, ridership across the MTA system dropped to 5 Million (a decrease of over ↓83%).
Another way to look at this is that 19% of passengers are still riding the MTA
steps.step-description: gradient fills in between reference bands

steps.text: This decline was not felt uniformly across the city. The changes in ridership vary greatly across different stations and communities.
We wanted to understand this better so we looked at census data for the neighborhood surrounding each subway station.
Specifically, we wanted to ask questions such as ‘Who is able to stay at home?’ and ‘Which communities are most at risk?’
steps.step-description: map stays the same, text updates

steps.text: Questions such as these are deeply entangled with the realities of deep, systemic racial and economic inequalities in our city.
steps.step-description: map stays the same, text updates

steps.text: For example, take the stations within the SoHo-TriBeCa-Civic Center-Little Italy Neighborhood.
steps.step-description: zoom into neighborhood - SoHo-TriBeCa-Civic Center-Little Italy

steps.text: This neighborhood saw an average decline of 90%-95% in ridership.
steps.step-description: zoom into neighborhood - SoHo-TriBeCa-Civic Center-Little Italy

steps.text: Contrast this with the ridership  within the Brownsville Neighborhood.
Here we saw an average decline of 60% in ridership. That means that 40% are still riding the subway.
To understand this better, let’s explore these stations away from their geographic locations and look at the relationship between change in ridership and various social and economic factors.
steps.step-description: dots rearrange themselves into beeswarm distribution view

steps.text: Here we can see the overall distribution of change in ridership across all the stations in the city.
